sols_html:
Polynomial division shows us that \(\frac{x^3 + x^2}{x^2 + 1} = (x+1) + \frac{-x-1}{x^2 + 1}\). Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{x^3 + x^2}{x^2 + 1} - (x+1) &= \frac{-x-1}{x^2 + 1} \\ \lim_{x \to \pm\infty} [f(x) - (x+1)] &= \lim_{x \to \pm\infty} \frac{-x-1}{x^2 + 1} \\ \lim_{x \to \pm\infty} [f(x) - (x+1)] &= 0\end{aligned}\]

Hence \(\displaystyle {\color{blue} y = x +1}\) is a slant asymptote of \(\displaystyle f(x)\).
